Comment: Thank you Elkton for putting on a wonderful event and thank you  RG, and  Darling for the article and Eberhardt for the photos.  The Ft. Umpqua replica is very well done, as historically accurate as was feasible, and the sight of  it  with its red  Hudsons Bay Company flag is one of the amazing scenes on this beautiful drive to the coast.
  On a per capita basis Elkton must have more enthusiastic volunteers than any  other town in Oregon.  The event was capped off with its historic pageant which especially featured the finest bunch of kids that any town would be proud of.  For many visitors  who hadn't known of England's control¬†of Oregon through its forts, this was an eye opener as long buried history came alive.  

If there was any imperfection to a grand event, it was that Ft. Umpqua's role as as  the British Hudsons Bay Company's  "Bastion of Empire" and fur collecting center was somewhat lost in the hubub of living history characters and purveyors of American souvenir trinkets.

Comment: Actually, the environmentalists have long known about this.   Methane, CH4, is also flooding out of the arctic.   It has been known for years, and those of us who know about it have seen the bizarre photos of the first discoveries of those little methane leaks that the Russians lit up like blowtorch turn into gaping holes and miles of champagne-like bubbles seeping out of the arctic ocean.   

People, scientists and others who understand  the issue, have long known that the earth stores CO2 and CH4, and that man-made warming would cause the release of those greenhouse gasses.   There is even a term for this effect - it is called "positive self-reinforcing feedback loops."   

Don't be fooled by the "positive" part; it's not a good thing.  Loss of the albedo is a very famous positive self-reinforcing feedback loop.    It's one of the things scientists and environmentalists warned people about.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AjZaFjXfLec

Comment: Part 1/2
I chose, earlier, to avoid that critique of the article but I'll try to wade into it, now.  The term "dialogical" may refer to:
1. an actual dialog between two sides in opposition attempting to reason to a consensus
2. an Hegelian dialectic wherein everything is circumscribed by time and subject to change
3. a form of logical game with each opponent trading arguments under formalized rules to reach a formal truth
4. a reference to "literary dialog" where ideology supersedes any other important consideration (logic, addressability, culture, etc.)
If the author means 2. the proper term would have been "dialectical" and I can see elements of this in the summary by the writer.  I don't see that 1. or 3. are meant in any specific way, leaving 4. (provided I captured all of the possible meanings).

Comment: Google "duplex townhomes" to see images.

"Duplex" means exactly two attached dwellings.

"Townhouse" or "townhome" is loosely defined, but commonly means two or more attached dwellings, each with two or more stories.

Another term, "rowhouse," is also loosely defined, but commonly means attached dwellings, each with two or more stories, and the entire row facing the street. "Classic" rowhouses ran for an entire block (or more).

-- Paul

Comment: JUST SAYING....... When the Environmental Impact Study was released, journalist could have questioned flawed logic that justified rail.  In Chapter 1 of the EIS it stipulated that a survey of residents in the rail corridor identified traffic congestion during the commute period as the biggest concern. In justifying rail the EIS stipulated that by 2-1 margin residents responded that improving transit was more important than building more roadways.  But such logic was flawed and rigged for rail.  First of all most commuters preferred traffic congestion reduction - not transit. Second of all, traffic congestion reduction without building more roads was already being introduced - on the highway and on the streets in 2005 - the 5th year of the 21st century.  And the state DOT at that time already had a Highways Modernization Plan: Oahu Projects. Until today, we have yet to hear of Traffic Congestion Reduction from the city DTS and state DOT.

Comment: The Jews were in such awe of God's name, that they developed the convention of NEVER pronouncing it out loud. Although the written Hebrew text remained Yahweh, the reader substituted the word "Adonai" and read that aloud to their synagogue congregation. The word "adonai" simply means "lord," a word reserved for addressing aristocrats. 

When the Jews translated the OT into Greek, they substituted "kyrios" (Greek for lord) for the Hebrew Yahweh. Early Christians adopted the Greek NT, and thus inherited this translations "error." When the Greek was translated into Latin, we got "dominus" (Latin for lord), and when the Latin was translated into English we got "Lord."

However, modern translations are direct from Hebrew to English, so translators have to decide between truthfully translation Yahweh as Yahweh, or adopting the Jewish convention.

I suspect, but have not checked, that the substitution of "God" for "Lord" is an attempt at a middle ground. Lord is wrong; that is not God's name.

Comment: Three things come to mind here.  The first:

1)  There seems to be a view of the Eucharist proposed by some (including perhaps the present pope) that verges on magical thinking:  the notion that the Eucharist is some sort of spiritual vitamin that perks us up--the corollary being that if you don't receive Communion you run the risk of becoming spiritually malnourished.  So it follows that it can only be 'merciful' to open Communion up to the divorced-and-remarried, and indeed (following the logic further) to all comers.

While we can't expect to hammer out a complete Eucharistic theology in a combox, I'd suggest this view is in many ways deficient.  An alternative is one in which the Eucharist encourages us to repent of our sins and reform our lives.  Instead of insisting that the Eucharist be supplied to us, we should move towards personal holiness and thus be bring ourselves closer to the sacrament.

Comment: I applaud your attempt to put a true dollar figure on fees.  However, you are making some very basic "time value of money" mistakes.  Adding $ figures from various time periods significantly distorts the analysis.

I believe the proper approach is to look at the returns with & without the fees and compare the results.

For example with various investment returns & a period of 50 years you would get the following Future Values based on a Present Value of $100,000: (Future = Present * (1+i) ^ n)    i=.05 for 5%

Return = 5%.  Future Value (Present Value assuming  2.5% inflation)
No fees:         $ 1,146,740 ($ 333,645)
1.0% Trailer:  $ 710,668 ($ 206,763)
2.5% MER:   $ 343,711 ($ 100,000)

Return = 7.5%  Future Value
No fees:         $ 3,718,975 ($ 1,082,007)
1.0% Trailer:  $ 2,330,668 ($ 678,090)
2.5% MER:   $ 1,146,740 ($333,635)

Comment: Protesters incorrectly claim the tribes were not consulted. Federal court records document ‚Äúdozens of attempts‚Äù to consult. Project leaders participated in 559 meetings with community leaders, local officials, and organizations to fine-tune the route. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers held 389 meetings with 55 tribes.  

Standing Rock Sioux ignored requests for comment and cancelled meetings.  In September 2014, they ignored five attempts to meet.  In October, upon arrival at an arranged meeting, Tribal Chairman David Archambault said the meeting had started early and was now over. In a November meeting, the tribe took the pipeline off the agenda and refused to discuss it. This stonewalling continued for a year and a half. 

The court record shows the Standing Rock Sioux refused to meet with corps officials to discuss the route until after site work had begun. That work is now 77 percent complete at a cost of $3 billion. 

These are facts upheld by two US federal courts.  No sympathy.

Comment: "The official said a drone operated by Russians was flying over a hospital as victims of the attack were rushing to get treatment. "

I wonder, what does this actually prove? The Syrian-Russian account of the attack is that they were bombing a suspected rebel chemical weapons factory. If that were true, then they could have sent the drone to monitor whether there were casualties from that attack. That is not to say that the Syrian-Russian version is true, only that this supposed piece of evidence proves nothing.

A Huffington Post article (http://huff.to/2nu5R56) points out that rebel forces have previously been found to have crude chemical weapons mixing chlorine gas and white phosphorus. If the chemical involved had been sarin, those attending to the victims would have needed protective gear, but several photos show this was not used. Once again, difinitive conclusions cannot be drawn, but without a thorough investigation we cannot conclude that Assad's regime launched the attack.

Comment: I'll offer an alternative view in good faith... Informative trail signs in the backcountry can be a boon to safety, but there's nothing wrong with expecting trail users in an urban area to have some idea of where they are by using a trail map or their own judgment. A fair number of large, obtrusive signs with no information on them have been erected to no purpose, other than to advertise who put them up. The smaller kiosk-style, information-laden signs will help those who can't help themselves. But the expensive, billboard-style placards without information are overkill. The South Platte corridor is now badly over-signed. Just sayin' there's a limit that should be based on what's useful, in good taste, and a wise use of taxpayer monies.

Comment: America's voting system is severely flawed. A majority of GOP voters disapprove of Trump, i.e., a majority would approve of anyone but Trump. But which anybody? Ay, there's the rub. By starting with such a large field, and having early voters select the candidates they most wanted‚Äîbut which were not politically viable (remember Ben Carson?)‚Äîthe GOP knowingly or not shot itself in the foot.

This is a classic collective action problem. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_action#Collective_action_problem Or more prosaically a failure to "bell the cat." http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belling_the_cat

Any reasonable preference voting system would have saved the GOP from themselves, and left them with a candidate not abhorred by so many. Perhaps we can look forward to the GOP pushing for true progressive electoral reform to more faithfully reflect the will of the voters. Or perhaps not.

Comment: One answer to JuJu Bean: if compassion isn't your thing, try self-interest. Providing for the homeless improves quality of life for everybody.  Ask people in downtown Seattle or San Francisco.  They think giving homeless people better options is worth real money, since otherwise they simply congregate and camp in public areas.  Policing them isn't effective (ties up too much manpower).  Pushing them out just moves the problem elsewhere.  And, though it may disappoint you, a Darwinian solution isn't available; we can't let people simply die on our streets.

The first reason housing is so effective is that it disperses a population that otherwise has little choice but to hang out together wherever they are tolerated. The second is that housing gives otherwise hopeless people a motive to start taking better care of themselves.  A third is that housing keep children off the streets and out of cars; even a Darwinian should be able to see the point of saving children.

Comment: I'm a college student that's much more religious than my parents.  I went to a Catholic high school but public grade schools.  From my perspective, going to a Catholic schools does nothing for students' faith.  If anything it weakens it.  The reason for this is twofold: one is the poor catechesis in so many schools that focuses on "social justice" rather than the core teachings of the Church, second is simply the fact that it is school.  Because Catholicism is homework, it automatically becomes an obligation.  

The solution would be one of two extremes: either to intensely educate kids about the deep theology and thinking behind Catholicism, or take a hands-free approach and try to plant a seed of curiosity about the Faith which will blossom with maturity.  The second option is closer to my own experience, but also riskier.

Comment: A burning bush moment...
reading Yves Congar's "I believe in the Holy Spirit" and discovering that my 'lived' theology was thin on the Holy Spirit. A 2+ Trinity isn't really a Trinity. I say lived because there is what I can read that eventually sifts down to my heart and out through my life. There was the renaming... from Ghost to Spirit. That helped. Confirmation talk about Gifts and something about how they become fruits... And then, the Charismatics sort of put an umbrella over the whole topic. That was about it. I spent countless hours carving wood, making wood chips, and contemplating some of Merton's insights. The Trinity is dark from the outside... after a while I stopped making wood chips. What was left I called Trinity.

Congar's three volume is hardly that. But I know when I am reaching beyond what I'm ready for... so, I turned the pages and offered my prayer to enlarge my heart. I will revisit. Perhaps, this here is an invitation to try again.

Comment: Real life experience: I was attacked by a feral cat a relative regularly allowed into the house. While I was sitting, watching television, it leaped up, unprovoked, to bury its fangs deeply into my bare forearm resting on the arm of the chair. After cleaning and bandaging the bite wounds, the doctor at a nearby clinic gravely told me that I needed to get to an emergency room immediately. Signs of serious infection started appearing throughout the arm. The doctor at the emergency room said I was lucky that the membrane covering the bone in my forearm was not punctured. It took a lot of family pressure to get the relative to comply with quarantine procedures. Even six months later, the skin around the punctures showed redness and skin flaking.

On a number of issues (not all), we aren't polarized because we have fundamental differences of opinion, we're polarized because one side of the argument is objectively detached from reality. If there's no framework for logical arguments and no value placed on what's objectively true or false, why would anyone think the two sides would agree? Sadly, trying to have a substantive conversation with someone who's constantly exposed to this alternative knowledge system, is pretty much pointless -  at least in my personal experience.

Comment: I feel compelled to comment on this, being a parent of a 19 year old boy. We have traveled with him to Europe and Asia where there are no legal drinking ages for consumption (not sure what the legal age is for purchase in France). We realize he drinks at least some alcohol when his is with his college buddies. When we are home together, we offer a small amount of whatever we are drinking with dinner (beer or wine) to model good social drinking behavior. We have zero tolerance for drinking and driving (even a small amount) and we have discussions about the difference between social drinking and binge drinking. Every family should examine their own behavior around alcohol, assess their own child and then decide what makes sense. Personally I would never "bring the party home" because that promotes binge drinking, which is extremely dangerous.

Comment: There are more missteps than favourable ones, but the missteps fall by the wayside and the plusses accumulate.  "Survival of the fittest" is misunderstood as it conjours images of evolutionary warfare.  By "fittest" it means that which is best suited to its environment and hence gradually over time the genes that give a creature an advantage, however small, will replace those that do not. The cumulative effect is evolutionary.

To simplify the your two positions above, we are here due to either:

A natural process, the early moments of which we can currently only speculate about but that developed via a mechanism for which there IS a wealth of evidence; or
Creation by supernatural entity for which no specific evidence exists, by way of a process that no-one has ever even tried to explain beyond "he (she) just did it".

The second option is easier on the brain, but reasonable? 2,000 years ago, maybe, today? No.

"I don't know" is fine. Others are working on filling the god-shaped gaps.

I can't help but feel for the families that Omar Khadr shattered.  I know what it's like growing up without a father. Comment: Ironically, those who learn English as a second language have larger vocabularies than native English-speakers.  I suspect it's because more reading goes into mastering the language than is the case with those born into most English-speaking households, thus providing greater access to seldom-used terminology.  

Evidence of this is that so many of our current, barely-literate generation seem shocked and confused by the term "dotard".  Several prominent works of English prose published since WWII use "dotard" and "dotage".  One which readily comes to mind is Professor J. R. R. Tolkein's "The Lord of the Rings."

Modern English-speakers' ignorance of their own language is as common in the UK as it is here--a shame as it has more words than most other languages, so more descriptive terminology is lost; it's also not much fun when an insult isn't understood.  But languages change over time--it would take a Professor Tolkein to render Old English into a form most of us could understand.

Comment: If you read the reasons carefully, the judge is relying on a theory that the complainant was able to consent right until the point that she was unconscious.  Though I have little experience of people passing out drunk, in cases I have witnessed, they are obviously not competent in the minutes leading up to passing out.  It isn't an instantaneous change. Indeed, the law is that someone can be incapacitated by alcohol and unable to consent before the point of being unconscious -- surely the minutes before passing out would be that degree of incapacity.  

Also note the judge specifically stated that the arrest and charges were justified given the circumstantial evidence that suggested there was an assault (and Blatchford's shock that he then contends that no evidence of assault was presented).  

The Crown is obliged to drop charges if they deem there is no possibility of conviction, not just because they think they might not win.  The latter would be to allow the Crown to be the judge.

Comment: Your explanation for Jesus' commandment against divorce is rubbish, no matter how many times you smugly state it.  This is NOT what Jesus said:  "Amen, amen I say to you, that because women are treated like chattel, I, Jesus, perfect liberal that I am, now tell you brothers:  No man or woman shall divorce (except for adultery) because it is the put-away wife who gets screwed.  This will change in time, but until then, what I tell you is the will of God."  That's not what happened.  Jesus told us the reason for his commandment against divorce:  "What God hath joined together  . . ." You may disagree with Jesus' reasoning, but that was his stated reason, the only one he mentioned.

Your logic also overlooks that divorce was allowed for one (and only exception):  adultery.  If Jesus forbade divorce only, or even mainly, to protect married women, he would have allowed women (and only women) to divorce on additional grounds (e.g. severe physical abuse or attempted murder).

Comment: When I was in Victoria  two years ago, a cougar wandered down the street on which my hotel was located - just two blocks from the B.C. legislature. Rather than shoot the cougar, the police cleared the area and waited for wildlife authorities to arrive. Within a fairly short time, the wildlife people showed up and had the situation in hand. They shot the cougar with a tranquilizer dart and removed it from the area soon afterwards. If police and authorities in other jurisdictions can handle such situations calmly and rationally without firing a hail of bullets, why can't police in Ontario deal with them in the same mature manner? Will it take a misfired bullet killing an innocent bystander before the troglodytes on our police forces enter the 21st century and adopt a rational, humane approach? I agree that bears, cougars and other animals can be dangerous but the biggest danger to our safety is all too often posed by two-legged animals who are authorized to carry lethal weapons.

Comment: "Why do you and other [sic] keep bringing up the % of people who voted?"

I can't speak for others, but I bring it up because it's good to remember that this president was elected without a popular mandate. And, since you mentioned Hillary Clinton, it's also important to keep in mind that millions who pulled the lever for Trump did so first and foremost to keep her out of office, not out of fondness for him.

In other words, the narrative that Trump rode some massive wave of populist support is not accurate. What is accurate is that he ran against an historically weak opponent and still wasn't able to win a plurality of the votes. 

Still, it's fair to point out that the election was in November and opinions have changed since then. But the election results do provide a baseline against which to measure the rise or decline of Trump's popularity, which has steadily gone down in the months since he took office.

Rasmussen, by the way, tends to skew Republican. Gallup is more neutral.

Comment: AC and DC will see the same voltage drop from conductor resistance.  Both require high voltages for transmission efficiency.  The reason AC 'won' was that it has always been easy and relatively inexpensive to change voltage using AC to AC transformers.
    DC actually has several advantages over AC in transmission to include the capability for higher voltages and it does not require synchronization.  The limiting factor now is the cost.  Due to almost a century of using AC and increased complexity, the DC/DC transformers in particular and DC circuit breakers are much more expensive.

Comment: Great post and awesome discussions!  I would like to point out however, that complaints against members are not brought forth by the DPH or the County Committees.  Complaints are filed by members themselves who feel the Bylaws have been broken. 

The issue becomes about the Bylaws and the importance to having them.  Are they important?  If not, should be abolish them? The Bylaws clearly state that registered Democrats are not to support registered members of other parties when a Democrat is also on that same ticket...for years this was ignored and perhaps that was fine, but now people are referring to those Bylaws and filing complaints.

It's the duty of the Party to uphold the Bylaws that have been adopted and to be unbiased when rendering punishments of same. All complaints are handled per the Bylaws and come down to a vote by Committee members. 

We have the opportunity to amend Bylaws during County & State Conventions. So maybe we need to start rethinking Bylaw language?

Comment: Yes, I put the term 'misdemeanours' in single quotes, in order to alert the reader that I was using the term in a general sense.

Two identical acts, yet the context in which they happen brings very different legal consequences. The fact that some couples find hair-pulling during sex stimulating adds to the incongruence.

Comment: Paul, we have done our research, and encourage you to do the same.  Past the three mile limit, state sovereignty ends. Alaska can receive some royalty from 3 to 6 miles out by federal law.  But after 6 miles- where Shell and others have proposed development, Alaska gets NOTHING.

Gulf Coast states like LA, TX, AL, and MS get 37.5% of royalties, but even this is capped at $375 million, annually.  

You are deflecting to other issues to ignore the fundamental point- that Alaska derives no revenues past six miles offshore.  Property taxes are not going to be paid to local government for offshore rigs.  But even if they did, local governments would have to spend a significant amount of money to develop infrastructure, personnel, and training to deal with an oil spill- that can not be cleaned up in broken sea ice.

Final point.  Why would you want off shore oil competing with oil from state leases?  This is a point your side ignores, or does not comprehend the significance of.

Comment: Great article Russell!  You're absolutely right.  Pollinators at risk include native bees and also various flies and beetles.  All of these invertebrates are susceptible to toxic chemical residues. One concerning to me in the PNW region is the application of products to remove moss from yards or rooftops.    I've observed bees and flies on mossy, spongy surfaces where they can drink without risk of drowning.   Clean water is important. Pollinators drink water just like we do.   Also worth mentioning...while research is now addressing the toxicity of active ingredients in some herbicides and fungicides, very little attention has been paid to the so-called inactive (inert) ingredients or adjuvants.  Many times, it's impossible to even find out what these are.  Usually they include an oil or soap to enhance delivery of the active ingredient.  These are also toxic to pollinators.  Unfortunately regulation of these products tends to favor industry and economics over environmental ecology.

Best time to travel to Cancun for example is mid January to mid April, because of the dry season, but I would not travel to any resort, surrounded by swamp or jungle.  I would pick a resort in a built up area with many other resorts around.   I definitely would not travel from August to December.   Odds are less than 5% of any problems even if one does contact zika in pregnancy, but I myself would never chance disability when in my power.  Excuse my fear. Comment: Well done Mark! It's a complicated issue and you've made it easier to understand. Distributed generation has the potential to democratize the electricity business by providing customers with more choices. Enlightened regulators should be willing to provide tariff certainty to self-generators / storers so that they can confidently pencil projected revenue (and savings) streams over a period of years. In today's electricity world, a LDC may offer demand response payments and time of day metering savings but there's no assurance that they won't alter their tariffs on a moment's notice. With say 5 years of forward certainty on tariffs, a customer can make a more informed case for investing in generation or storage equipment. The hub and spoke system has been a useful delivery mechanism for power but with advancements in technology, there's a case to be made for sharing the "avoided cost" savings with customers willing to make the investment themselves.

Comment: I have a copy of the Ontario summary of the  PISA report in front of me and it is not as good as the article makes out.
Since 2000 there has been no change in Canada's average score in science, ranging from 529 in 2000 to 534 in 2006 back down to 528 in 2000.  
Ontario ranked just slightly below Canada through most of those years (a couple years it was higher) but not statically different.
What is interesting is that they highest scores in Ontario for math and science occurred in the years where the students were primarily educated under the system developed by the Conservative governments of Mike Harris and Ernie Eves.   It makes you wonder if teacher testing (really just effective employment review) had an impact and if all the money Dalton and Wynne had any positive effect on educational outcomes.

Comment: The winner-take-all method of awarding electoral votes became dominant only in the 1830s, when most of the Founders had been dead for decades, after the states adopted it, one-by-one, in order to maximize the power of the party in power in each state. 

The constitutional wording does not encourage, discourage, require, or prohibit the use of any particular method for awarding a state's electoral votes.
	
States have the responsibility and constitutional power to make all of their voters relevant in every presidential election and beyond. 

Given the historical fact that 95% of the U.S. population in 1790 lived in places of less than 2,500 people, it is unlikely that the Founders were concerned about candidates winning only in big cities. 

Direct democracy is a form of government in which people vote on all policy initiatives directly. 

Popular election of the chief executive does not determine whether a government is a republic or democracy.

Comment: No.  Just no.  You have a full time nanny and a work space that is physically separated from your home?  that's not working from home with kids.  Working from home with kids is having the baby strapped to your chest for a nap while you sit at the computer.  It's balancing your need to finish something with your guilt over letting your kids spend another hour playing video games so you will be able to finish it.  It's never having more than 15 minutes in a row to do anything because 15 minutes is the longest your toddler will ever play with anything by herself.   It's learning how to do 8 hours of work in the 5 hours that your kids spend in school.  

Nothing wrong with having a nanny.  But handing childcare to someone else for 8 hours every day so you can get your work done is *not* working home with kids.

Comment: It's part of the Federal interstate system, there can be no "overreach" there. Though the original intent was primarily to enhance the national economy, "create jobs," and enable trade, note that all the formative legislation contains at least a nod to the enumerated power of the government to enable effective national defense by creating a road network sufficient to move troops cross-country and provide for effective evacuation of major cities in the case of, per the '50s Acts, atomic attack. Not to mention the explicit power to create/maintain a system of "Post Roads."

There is some hypocrisy in how some people oppose some Federal spending but not all, but you can only determine if hypocrisy exists if you look at the precise objections based on the given justifications for the given spending. Use of enumerated powers for (more or less) their explicitly intended purposes is different than coming up with emanations and penumbrae post facto to justify doing something that sounds nice.

Comment: I think sometimes, we miss what's laying right in front of us, as we look to find "something bigger." For all the media hype/spin (OMG, did Trump say THAT????, or compare president X versus president Y's response, etc...), the REAL story was not partisan politics, it was not racism, it was not sexual politics, religion or anything else.

The real story in the Houston floods was that "rednecks" from Louisiana created a VERY long caravan of people pulling flat-bottomed boats, heading IN to Houston, to help rescue people. The real story in Las Vegas was the number of everyday people who put their own lives on the line and dove back INTO the concert venue to try to help get others out, even as a crazed madman was still shooting.  Etc...

The real story here is consistent: when the chips are down, people rise above racism, sexism, economic disparity and religion. Everyday people set ALL of that aside to help each other. To me, THAT's what to watch for in all of this, not the talking heads.

Comment: I think with immigration there are many factors that determine whether immigrants assimilate well or not.  I would argue the reason Canada has worked quite well while Europe has had plenty of problems is two fold.

1.  Criteria for immigration - Canada focuses mainly on economic immigrants who are most likely to make a positive impact and likewise the more educated and more skilled one is the easier they will find it to integrate into a different culture.  In Europe much of their immigration was to fill low skilled jobs no one wanted.

2.  Tolerance of the host culture - If immigrants feel they are welcomed and valued they are more likely to reciprocate and integrate whereas if they feel they are not wanted and see as outsiders, they are less likely to which is the problem in much of Europe.

If GDP growth is the goal, then we see similar patterns as all the countries that set out on this trajectory a while ago, like the US: lobbying overtaking democratic function, wanton environmental destruction and an increasing wealth divide.

You'd think that in South Africa we'd have a greater understanding of the social importance of equality.

Comment: "The plan to increase income taxes on wealthy residents to finance an earned income tax credit for lower income people amounts to transferring money from the rich to the poor, which is something the tax system was not designed to do," he [Yamachika] said.
Increasing income taxes on the wealthy is NOT a transfer, it's a simple issue of fairness. The poorest 20% of Hawaii residents pay the highest percentage of their incomes in taxes (12%), while the wealthiest pay the least (top 5% pay about 6 percent of their incomes in state and local taxes), according to the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy. 
Kevin Dayton's one of the best reporters around, but he should have interviewed some third party organizations besides the anti-tax Grassroots Institute and the Tax Foundation, which is basically the lobbying arm of local corporations and the high rollers on their boards.

Comment: Thanks you so much for telling Canadians: "I didn‚Äôt feel a part of it and I began to understand why American backpackers travelling abroad stitched the Canadian maple leaf onto their knapsacks."

And its veracity is backed by two major scientific studies and careful polls, one found that between 1965 and 2015 a total of 54,255,603 Americans sewed one Canadian flag on their knapsack while visiting Europe (an additional 2,455, 705 sewed on more than one). Again, thank you.

Comment: The only reason for the parents to blame the school it to increase the pot of money for a suit and to deflect blame from themselves. Having worked in commercial insurance for nearly two decades, I saw a few suits in which the parents took businesses to court when they--the parents--were primarily responsible for their losses. The worst case involved a couple who had been separated. They met in a hotel to "work things out," enjoying a few drinks at a bar next to the hotel's indoor pool while their 6 year old son swam in the pool.  Although there were signs informing guests that there were no lifeguards on duty and that children under 12 must be accompanied by a responsible adult, the parents left their son alone in the pool as they went to a hotel room to "work things out."  The boy drowned.  The parents sued the hotel. and the hotel paid a "nuisance" claim.  The parents could point to the "award" and put the blame to the hotel rather than accepting their own responsibility.

Comment: In terms of effective public investment, the YUS and B-D subways are the best money the province ever invested in anything, except for the Adam Beck GS.
.
The idea that "all of the taxpayers of Ontario" are subsidizing the subways is complete nonsense.
.
The positive externalities to the private sector that have arisen from the YUS and B-D subways have paid for themselves a thousand times over.  Those subways are subsidizing the taxpayers of Ontario, not the other way around (i.e., expressed differently, they are paying their owners enormous dividends).
.
Don't think that's true?
.
Just try to get around in Toronto when the TTC is closed - or even when they are doing track maintenance on just a part of the system.  The City grinds to a halt.  The value of those two subways to Ontario is enormous.
.
The cost to the economy of not running those subways is far, far greater than the cost of running them.  They are an incredible bargain for the people of Ontario.

Comment: Yes.  The S&P 500 - an index of the 500 largest stocks in the US market.  With dividends reinvested and using at least a five year time horizon (anything can happen in the short-term) you can go back to basically any period in time over the last 30 years and your return is between 7 and 11%.  The lone exception is if you invested at the beginning of 2000 or 2001.  Then you'd be hit by the combo of the dotcom bubble (followed by 9/11) and the Great Recession.  Even here your return would be over 5%, which isn't bad considering it would literally be the worst time to invest in the last 100 years after the day before the Great Depression.
See: https://dqydj.com/sp-500-return-calculator/

If you  invest in a TFSA you won't pay any taxes.  If you invest in an RRSP you won't pay taxes until you withdraw.

Comment: The level of uncertainty is probably much less than the article suggests. Disbelief, angst, trepidation, even shock - yes, but I think the vast majority know, in their gut, exactly what is to come. They're just having a hard time getting their heads around it.

Even among those voted Trump there are no doubt many who'd like to have their time back. Many voted in a fit of pique - spurred on by an incompetent press, an unpopular Democratic nominee, an inept (or worse) FBI, a foreign scheme to derail American democracy, and a deep contempt for the political establishment among blue collar workers. The sad part is that the very people responsible for his ascendancy (the marginalized and disadvantaged) are the most likely to suffer under a Trump presidency.

Change can be good; upheaval less so. Americans weren't wrong to look for a change agent. Had they opted for Sanders as opposed to Trump, the next four years might have offered real promise.

Comment: Many moons ago PERA was overfunded, and the state was eager to reduce their contribution. PERA said, in effect, "Wait, those funds belong to the retirees, and because we have done a good job of investing, you shouldn't be able to reduce your contribution." Ultimately a compromise was reached which allowed the state to somewhat reduce their contribution, but also fixed the yearly benefit increase at 3%. Now neither the state nor the retirees want to take the hit that balancing the accounts will require. Having both parties feel some of the pain strikes me as the fairest way to solve the problem.

Comment: I was diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes and put on Metformin on June 26th, 2016. I started the ADA diet and followed it 100% for a few weeks and could not get my blood sugar to go below 140. Finally i began to panic and called my doctor, he told me to get used to it. He said I would be on metformin my whole life and eventually insulin. At that point i knew something wasn't right and began to do a lot of research. Then I found Lisa‚Äôs diabetes story (google " HOW EVER I FREED MYSELF FROM THE DIABETES " ) I read that article from end to end because everything the writer was saying made absolute sense. - what to watch out for (ie. indications of a release, etc)
- how to respond (ie. what to do and not do... vital info to know).

I phoned people, knocked on doors and stopped residents on the sidewalk: it was extremely rare to encounter someone who was aware of their nearby pipeline. 

This lack of awareness included staff and senior personnel at schools, high-rises, a hotel, a major transit hub, etc. 

Part of the problem is that NEB has no database of these "high-consequence sites." Comment: Spencer wrote  in his Principles of Biology, "This survival of the fittest, which I have here sought to express in mechanical terms, is that which Mr. Darwin has called 'natural selection', or the preservation of favoured races in the struggle for life." Darwin liked the phrase, as did  Alfred Russel Wallace, who had developed the theory of natural selection independently of Darwin (but Darwin published first -- after being made aware of Wallace's work). Darwin himself used it in some of the later editions of Origin of Species, meaning "better designed for an immediate, local environment".

Unfortunately, Spencer and some of his followers took the phrase in what they called a moral sense,  as an ethical precept that sanctioned cut-throat economic competition. Some of the more extreme Social Darwinists said that the poor should not be helped, since it would be aiding the "less fit" in surviving. They claimed that social caste was determined by natural superiority.

Comment: His ‚Äúcouncil‚Äù, the Pontifical Commission on Birth Control, was not advisory and had not been asked to make recommendations.

Pope John XXIII established a commission of six European non-theologians to study questions of birth control and population in 1963.

Pope Paul VI added theologians to the commission and expanded it to 72 members.

On its own initiative it produced a report in 1966 proposing that artificial birth control was not intrinsically evil.

John Ford, SJ, with Germain Grisez wrote a  working paper with three theologian priests on the commission stating that the Church could not change its long-standing teaching.

Paul VI‚Äôs delay in responding compounded his error in failing to direct the commission, and by the time Humanae Vitae was issued the damage had been done.

Comment: Much of what is reported in this interesting piece is aided and abetted by...instant communications; it becomes a catch-22: the means of communicating to millions anytime feeds on itself.  Thinking time is short because the ability to deliver a message is there, waiting and--worse--the Pres. is a tweet junkie. So many mistakes or "mispeaking" or "missteps" occur simply because there is little time to reflect, and a decision to "say nothing right now" is rare.  That's the sending end.  On the receiving end, much of the public are now 24/7 news junkies, slavering for updates even when there really aren't any.  Legitimacy is threatened.  Hence, "fake news."

Just a century ago, it was different: no instant mass communication. As most people did NOT live in cities, many never read one of the handful of daily newspapers.  Many were illiterate, most had no telephone.  News travelled more slowly; next week was good enough.  Result: Less "news."  Not today.  Result: chaos reign

Comment: We need more legislators like Karl Rhoads, who is standing up for justice for undocumented immigrants.  

An estimated 21,000 undocumented immigrants live in Hawaii.  Most have not committed any crime arising from their immigration status.  Many have lived in the US for years and have either married US citizens or have children who are US citizens by birth.  

Due to dysfunctional US immigration policy, most undocumented immigrants do not have a path to citizenship, despite the fact that they may have children who are US citizens. Comment: My gosh, Rationalis, you appear not to grasp the inherent contradiction in your own words. In the same sentence you say "abortion is the killing of a ... PERSON" and then "the fetus is a POTENTIAL person." 

When you say that the fetus is only a "potential person," you grant to the "pro-abortionist" philosopher the very essence of their argument. A potential human is not yet a full human, it is a life growing, developing towards full humanity. Since the fetus is, according to you, not yet fully a person, then the secular moral agreement that we can not take the life of persons, does NOT apply to the fetus.

Au contraire, the Catholic position is that the fetus is a full human being in the most essential manner that makes humans, humans from the perspective of our theology. The fetus has been "ensouled" (to use an older terminology that has its own problems) and is thus immortal long before it is born. For us immortality is the essential distinguishing feature of humans versus animals.

Comment: This makes sense on so many levels.  I think better housing options will improve life for many.  Loneliness is the modern plague and it is liable to get a lot worse before it gets better.  Over half of adults are single.  Today it's much less common to work at the same job for decades than it used to be.  We are social animals.  Co housing could meet some of our social needs in the same way a job does, not necessarily best friends for ever and ever but people  you see and interact with on a daily basis.  
It would be great to have housing communities that were flexible enough to accommodate people in various stages of life.  Single student, parent with child, retired adult, ailing elder.  
I think it makes sense to do this within families too - a family compound if you will.  Or even a group of friends living on the same street or apartment complex.

.

Comment: Slugs - homeless snails.
One rainy summer my neighbor's geese got loose and invaded my yard. In the few hours they were here, they gobbled up all the slugs I had been struggling to control. Unfortunately, it seemed that for every slug they ate, they left 5 piles of goose-poop. Everywhere.
The cake-pan of beer (sunk into the soil up to the rim) works really well. As Mr. Lowenfels says, locate them away from the garden, and they will draw slugs by the dozen.
Something else that I discovered by accident works to keep slugs out. Using 55-gallon drums cut in thirds as raised-bed containers is pretty common. I acquired several that were rusty. I hesitated to paint them because I didn't know what paint would be safe to use in the garden (plus it was time to get plants outside), so I left them rusty. Slugs will not climb up the rusty surface. I later got some that were newer and still had nice clean painted surfaces - the slugs climbed right up and made themselves at home.

Comment: I commute by bicycle and choose a route that avoids as much traffic as possible even though it adds mileage. I've been riding for 40 years and have seen a great improvement in bicycle acceptance and numbers of people commuting. The city isn't perfect in its layout for cycling, but it's pretty great compared to a lot of cities where I've ridden. 

There have always been polar arguments as to whether bicycles belong on the road. I think both parties should be accepting. I always thank the motorist with a wave when they yield me the right away whether I legally have it or not. I always respect their right of weight. I try to ride a predictable  manor so they're confident in passing me. I do this to try and create a sense of good will for all cyclists.

Comment: So why don't we tax water, which makes as much sense as taxing CO2?  Without water, all life on earth would perish.  The same is true of CO2, as below about 100 ppm, all plant life would perish due to its inability to engage in photosynthesis.  Burn this formula into your brain: 6CO2 + 6H2O + Light = C6H12O6 (Glucose) + 6O2.  It translates to 6 molecules of CO2 plus 6 molecules of water, in the presence of light energy, produces one molecule of glucose (a fundamental plant nutrient) plus 6 molecules of oxygen.  This is the most basic formula for life on earth.  If you want to eat or breathe, you'd best be thankful for CO2 and water, in equal proportion.

Comment: I can't speak to the specific case because I don't know enough about his situation. Retired on highly inadequate Social Security, I get around $140 a month in food stamps, which doesn't last the month. I'm fortunate that I live in subsidized housing so my rent is low, around 30 percent of income, so I get by as long as I'm careful. The need in Eugene for subsidized housing is much greater than the supply. 

Everyone's situation is different. The amount of food stamps you get is based on your income and other considerations such as how many people you're supporting. 

Nationally, food stamp amounts are inadequate. especially for people with kids, and do not last the month. The states run the program, and a lot of them are very restrictive. A whole lot of people in this country are struggling just to survive. To get the picture from the inside, I recommend the book "Hand to Mouth: Living in Bootstrap America" by Linda Tirado. I've also seen some good documentaries on Netflix.

Comment: Glad to hear you are alright. 

My father had experiences in both U.S. and Canadian hospitals for heart conditions. By and large care in both places was good. In the U.S., however, when you left, you took everything with you (such as basins) because you'd paid for everything so you might as well take it. Also my father had travel insurance so he didn't have to wait for all the 'insured people' to be treated before they got to him (maybe if you are having a heart attack when you show up in Emerg, they wave that rule; not sure.)

Also, you had an EMERGENCY in LA, whereas you getting follow-up care when you returned to Canada. So it is a bit unfair to compare the two situations.  So to be fair, you ought to have shown up at the hospital in both countries with an emergency. 

And if you have insurance in the U.S., that is a completely different game than if you don't have insurance.

Also the U.S. system is 2 X more expensive than ours.

Comment: I was working for the Alaska Railroad as a fork lift operator in Denali at the old depot. It was the summer of 99 and my first morning opening up the building around 5 or 6 am. As I crossed the tracks towards the depot I spotted this large mass to my left. Thirty feet down the tracks a Lynx stood going the other way, and it was staring me down. I froze. It looked the size of a Labrador, with matted twisted hair like dreadlocks. A moment passed with little pace. Then the gigantic cat put it's nose to the ground with ears fidgeting.  And with an unsettling grace of movement it made its way to the tree line and vanished silently. My heart was pounding.

When asked why not let the south go Lincoln replied where shall I get my revenue.  The south provided some 80% off federal revenue in 1861 and Lincoln would not let it go. 
If you condider freedom self determination and the United States constitution positive ideas then one has to also consider the Confederate battle flag a positive symbol as it embodies all three.

Comment: We witnessed part of the initial contact. He was our neighbor and a friend, he was really good friends with our close friends who were involved in helping LE over the phone, to help LE know who and what they were dealing with! We are very sadden and heart broken that it ended this way. LE who continued to show up and then evacuated us to safety were very professional and concerned with everyones safety, One thing I can say about this place is the community and it's efforts are amazing! I am grateful. Prayers for this man's Family and friends. RIP.

I will not disguss the matter in detail out of respect for this man's family and the Police who are investigating. We still need to give our statements to LE.

Comment: I was rolled twice on a motorcycle, then slowed to 10 mph, I tried staying back 50 yards, but the car behind me honked at me like the driver didn't see a huge plume of black in front of me. Comment: "The policies of the federal government relating to the classification of marijuana as a Schedule I drug are there for a reason, and that is to protect the health and welfare of our public..."
Aloha D Perry,
Your opening remark (above) is simply inaccurate.  Ethanol is legal and is a decidedly higher risk to "the health and welfare of our (sic) public". It will stay legal because we value personal choice.
Mr Perry, do you realize that Richard Nixons staff person John Erlichman recently confirmed what many of us suspected; that the intent of the 'drug war' was to disrupt black/brown communities as well as the counter-culture and antiwar activists. 
The drug war achieved its intended result. Mass incarceration and prison profits on an unprecedented level. 
Your contention is that cannabis is a health threat. You don't have data to back up this claim.
But, for discussion sake, lets say you do. So what? It is not your job to prohibit a relatively benign and widely used natural substance.

Comment: The major reason why there is no big groundswell of protest against Trump and no big movement to remove him from power is that the opposition "resistance" is held in no less contempt by the large majority of Americans.

   The Democratic opposition represented by daily media attacks against Trump is regarded as the "lesser of two evils", and even Americans are unhappy about supporting evil.

   Obsessed with their hatred of Trump (who in reality has done very little that a President Hillary wouldn't have done), the Democrats and their media backers have utterly refused to present an alternative vision with alternative policies and an alternative leader that Americans can regard as a viable alternative.

  So Americans keep calm and carry on, knowing the billionaire corporate establishment oligarchy is ruling America and the world. While Trump provides a daily show of entertaining diversion from their frustrations, Americans know it's business as usual.
